Dear Dr. Taylor:
Mrs. Joshi returns for followup. Currently, she complains of
exertional fatigue, exertional dyspnea, and mild peripheral
edema. Since last seen, she has continued to find it quite
difficult to lose weight, and has thus far declined seeing
members of our obesity clinic. As you know, in the past, she
also has declined any consideration of attempted cardioversion or
other invasive studies. Presently, she remains on a regimen of
enteric-coated aspirin 325 mg p.o. q.d., simvastatin 20 mg p.o.
q.d., metoprolol 50 mg p.o. b.i.d., isosorbide nitrate 60 mg p.o.
q.d., Avapro 150 mg p.o. q.d., Actos 45 mg p.o. q.d., potassium,
10 mEq p.o. q.d. Pumex 2 mg p.o. q.d., Coumadin, magnesium oxide,
Humulin insulin 20 units subcutaneous q. a.m. along with 50 units
subcutaneous q. p.m., and Humalog 26 units subcutaneous q. a.m.
Physical examination reveals a markedly overweight woman in no
acute distress. Blood pressure right arm sitting at 106/62,
heart rate 65 and irregularly regular, respirations 16 and
unlabored, weight 306 lbs, which is 6 lbs above her weight 10
months ago. The neck is soft. JVP is flat. Carotids without
significant bruits. Chest is clear. Cardiac exam reveals a
normal S1, a physiologically split S2, with a1-2/6 systolic
murmur radiating from apex to the base. No significant diastolic
murmur or rub. The abdomen is obese, but otherwise benign.
Extremities reveal 1-2+ bipedal edema, peripheral pulses are
intact albeit mildly diminished.
Electrocardiogram shows atrial fibrillation with a variable QRS
response. The P waves are more organized than one might usually
see, suggesting the possibility of fibrillation/flutter as well.
QRS 0.11, QT 0.38, axis 90 degrees, there is evidence of a prior
inferior myocardial infarction. Compared with his last
electrocardiogram, there is no significant change.
Impression: Mrs. Joshy continues to suffer from morbid obesity,
and I had a long discussion with her and her daughter regarding
the essential nature of her engaging in an aggressive weigh
reduction program. I once again have strongly encouraged her to
make an appointment with our obesity clinic to assist in
extensive weight reduction. I also discussed with her my
concerns regarding her symptoms of slowly progressive peripheral
edema, particularly as it pertains both to her weight, and atrial
or tachyarrhythmias. As in the past, she told me that she would
refuse any consideration for attempted cardioversion or other
studies. She did, however, agree to continue with her current
medical regimen. I obtained routine blood studies today to
verify the adequacy of her lipid control and diabetes management.
I have introduced her to Hayden Nutter, her nurse practitioner, who
will assist in trying to achieve a little more diuresis overt he
next few weeks. We have given her a prescription for Zaroxylyn
to begin at 2.5 mg p.o. q.d., which will help result in some
degree of mild diuresis. Nonetheless, she understands that
significant weight loss can only occur through a weight reduction
program. I have of course explained to her the increased cardiac
morbidity associated with her current lifestyle. Beyond this, I
have not altered her current medical regimen.
Of course, I thank you for allowing me to assist in his care.
Sincerely yours,
